Expectation1: Maintain regular communication with family members
Situation1: A family holiday is approaching, which is a traditional time for everyone to reconnect.
Expectation2: Collaborate with other teams to define and design new features
Situation2: Product has scheduled a general brainstorming session next sprint where attendance is optional
Story: I stared at my phone, a message from my daughter lighting up the screen: “Dad, are you coming for the holiday dinner? The kids can’t wait to see you.” My heart warmed at the thought of my grandkids, their laughter echoing in my mind. Family holidays were sacred—my chance to reconnect, to be the grandfather who listens, who tells stories, who is present. But as I opened my laptop, a new email popped up from Product: “Optional brainstorming session next week—would love your input on the new features.” I knew “optional” really meant “we hope you’ll be there.” My team counted on me to help shape the project’s direction, and missing the session could mean losing my voice in decisions that would affect us all. I felt the tug from both sides—my family expecting my presence, my colleagues expecting my expertise. I sat at my desk, torn, the weight of both roles pressing in, unsure which expectation I could bear to disappoint.
